bibl.title: Letter from H. McG. Robertson to Henry Rose Carter, April 13, 1925

div1.p: Robertson discusses bubonic plague in temperate climates.

div1.head: Letter from H. McG. Robertson to Henry Rose Carter, April 13, 1925
div1.opener:
U. S. Marine Hospital
Chelsea, Mass,
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
April 13, 1925
Assistant Surgeon General
Henry R. Carter
Washington D. C.
My dear Doctor Carter:-
div1.p:
Please allow me
to thank you for your letter
of the 6th instant, containing references
to Bacot's work on rat fleas. It
was at your suggestion that I
Secured a copy of The Journal of
Hygiene, Plague Supplement, Vol XIII,
Jan. 1914, and read Bacots most
interesting article on the “Bionomics
of the common Rat Flea”. In this
article I found several things which
tended to explain the comparative
absence of Bubonic Plague in any
except the Warmest countries.
I am enclosing copy of several
2
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
paragraphs taken from the above
article. In par. X, page 487
you will note that a temperature
of 65°-70°F. is required for rapid
increase in the Number of fleas. and
that below 55°F. hatching is much retarded.
If you remember, in my study
of cases of Plague reported in
the P. H. R. for 26 years, it was shown
that 99.83 p. c. of cases had been
reported in countries with mean
Mid winter temperatures of 6556°F or
over ( The Similarity of temper-
atures is interesting. It must be
that in all temperate zones
the season when the thermometer
will average over 6556°F. is
very short. and the chances of
rodent plague correspondingly less.
3
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
This is to me an interesting subject,
as is also the question of Bubonic
Plague in Manchuria & Siberia.
This last, I firmly believe could
not exist except for the fact
that the hibernating Moorrat
carries over the infection from
Summer to Summer. I believe
you saw the enclosed comment
which I added to a review
of the Report of the Manchurian
Plague Commission, 1920-1921.
The Bureau would not publish
the review I wrote of this
Report, presumably because of
the “Note” which I am enclosing,
which was not intended for
publication. (I think I sent you
a copy of this Review of the time
I wrote it in Fall of 1923)
4
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
I should not, I suppose, allow
my interest in this subject to
stay too fresh after receiving
from the Bureau a letter with
the following sentence - “The For
your further information it maybe
stated that the Bureau regards”
your views “as by no means
well established, and, further,
that it is relatively unimportant
if true”. The reason being
that one bubonic rat could give
rise, say in Boston, to an
Epidemic of Pneumonic Plague.

However, I want to thank you
for your interest, and also
I should apologize for imposing
thus upon your time and patience.

With kindest regards for yourself
and family. I am
